skill.name: orchestrating-parallel-agents
skill.description: Spawns multiple AI coding agents to work on related GitHub issues concurrently using git worktrees. Use when breaking down a large feature into multiple issues, running parallel agents with --print flag, or managing wave-based execution of related tasks.
skill.summary: Spawns multiple AI coding agents to work on related GitHub issues concurrently using git worktrees. ...
skill.author: 4eyedengineer

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown instructions for git worktree-based parallel agent orchestration. No file system modifications, network calls, or external command execution by the skill itself.

content.user_title: Run Multiple AI Agents in Parallel
content.value_statement: Managing multiple related GitHub issues sequentially wastes time. This skill enables running several AI coding agents simultaneously using git worktrees, breaking large features into parallel waves of independent work for faster delivery.
actual_capabilities: Spawns multiple AI agents on separate git worktrees for concurrent work
Organizes issues into waves based on file dependencies
Provides issue templates with context for autonomous agent execution
Includes monitoring commands to track parallel agent progress
Documents manual completion steps for git operations that require user permissions
limitations: Requires pre-approved git permissions in settings.local.json for non-interactive use
Agents cannot push or create PRs without explicit git permissions
Same-file changes across issues require sequential merging or single-agent handling
Users must manually resolve merge conflicts between waves

use_cases.title: Scale Team Velocity
use_cases.description: Break large features into parallel workstreams and accelerate delivery by running multiple AI agents concurrently

use_cases.title: Parallel Infrastructure Work
use_cases.description: Implement backend, database, and API changes simultaneously while keeping frontend work in separate waves

use_cases.title: Feature Branch Isolation
use_cases.description: Run independent agents on different file changes without merge conflicts by organizing work into dependency-aware waves

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Spawn
prompt_templates.prompt: Use /worktree-issue to spawn agents for issues 101, 102, and 103 in parallel

prompt_templates.title: Wave-Based Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Break down the new authentication feature into 3 waves of independent issues using the parallel agents workflow

prompt_templates.title: Monitor Progress
prompt_templates.prompt: Check the status of running worktree-issue agents and identify any that need manual completion

prompt_templates.title: Complete and Merge
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete the remaining git commits for stalled agents and merge the wave 1 PRs sequentially

output_examples.input: Run parallel agents for issues 201 and 202 on the authentication feature
output: ✓ Created git worktrees for issues 201 and 202

best_practices: Keep each issue scoped to 1-3 files for higher success rates
Organize waves so independent changes run first
Include specific file paths and code snippets in each issue
anti_patterns: Spawning too many agents that exceed system resources
Putting same-file changes in different waves without coordination
Skipping manual review of agent-generated changes before merging

faq.question: What tools does this skill work with?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude Code and Claude. It uses the Task tool to spawn parallel agents.

faq.question: How many agents can run in parallel?
faq.answer: The limit depends on your system resources. Start with 2-3 agents and increase gradually while monitoring performance.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: Yes, you can run the parallel agents workflow locally and then use GitHub Actions for CI/CD validation of completed PRs.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only provides workflow guidance. All code changes are reviewed by you before git commits and PR creation.

faq.question: Why did my agent fail on git operations?
faq.answer: Agents need pre-approved git permissions. Add the required permissions to settings.local.json or complete git steps manually.

faq.question: How is this different from running multiple Claude sessions?
faq.answer: Git worktrees isolate changes to prevent conflicts, allow parallel work on the same repo, and make cleanup automatic.
